practices.description: Encouraging students to apply what they have learned in increasingly authentic, real-world contexts and/or in real-world-like problems.
Defining clear objectives and expectations to guide students.
Providing students with examples of the application or materialization of concepts through detailed, specific, and anecdotal real-life stories.
Engaging students in complex and authentic tasks that foster the development of practical skills under faculty supervision.
Challenging students to analyze, elaborate on new learning, and understand its theoretical and practical implications.

practices.practice: Relating Content to Students’ Lives and Interests
practices.description: Highlighting how new content connects with students’ personal contexts to facilitate integration with prior knowledge.
Designing curriculum activities that support the achievement of objectives and reflect assessments.
Providing students with problems to solve, actively applying previously addressed knowledge.
Providing students with clarity in both the representation of conceptual content, the relationships between ideas, and the progressive development of learning toward a well-defined purpose and goal.
Engaging students by stimulating their interest in course material to foster better learning outcomes.
Providing opportunities to recall previously learned ideas from memory
Engage students in peer evaluation or peer teaching.
Encouraging students to ask questions and participate in discussions inside or outside the classroom.
Instructor availability and willingness to help students or answer questions.
Ensure that the course content is delivered clearly and understandably to improve student learning.
Class visual resources (such as presentations or others) are understandable and facilitate content comprehension.
Allowing students to witness problem-solving or reasoning so that thought processes, planning, or approaches become explicit.
Provide students with materials they can interact with beyond the classroom (quizzes, exercises, or others).
Demonstrating enthusiasm for the course or content to inspire students and create a positive learning environment.
Providing timely and high-quality feedback to help students understand their progress and areas for improvement.
Evaluation using situations, tasks, or standards similar to those that professionals usually face.
Students evaluate the quality of their peers’ work and provide feedback to one another.
Ensuring that exams are fair, well-structured, and aligned with learning objectives to accurately assess achievement.
Encouraging students to evaluate their own work, promoting reflection and self-awareness in learning.

practices.practice: Teacher Sensitivity to Class Level and Progress
practices.description: Adapting teaching and assessment practices to align with students’ current levels and progress.
Faculty use the same teaching-learning activities repeatedly or for a long-time within the lesson.
The course content, activities, or assignments do not present an interesting challenge for the students, their level of knowledge, and their skills.
The learning objectives omit relevant areas or, conversely, cover too many aspects to be manageable.
Goal statements are missing, non-transparent, unspecified, incomplete, or incomprehensible.

practices.practice: No guiding overviews about new contents
practices.description: Maps, organizers for gaining an impression or a first model on what must be learned are missing.
There are no tasks for students which activate prior knowledge and link it with new contents.
Summaries of prerequisite contents or evaluations of past work are missing.
There is no clear structure on contents, activities, or in time.

practices.practice: No support for integration of new knowledge
practices.description: There are no elaborative questions, illustrations, or worked examples.
There are no activities which demonstrate how to perform desired activities or which articulate the reasoning necessary for the activities.
There are no activities which monitor, analyze, and regulate the learners’ knowledge and skill developments.
The presentation of the content or assessment activities (e.g., assignments) does not match the students’ level of knowledge and skills.

practices.practice: No validation of assessment and grades
practices.description: There are no attempts to learn about and improve the criteria-based quality of assessments and resulting grading.
There is no feedback on the learning process which is explicit, goal-evaluative, specific, positive, and directive-preventive.
Feedback on learning is too delayed or too early, or irregular in time.

practices.practice: No suggestions to think about connections or analogies
practices.description: There are no activities in which students have to group problems or invent similar problems.

practices.practice: No application of knowledge and skills in different contexts
practices.description: Knowledge and skills are not applied in varying scenarios or with different experiences.

This includes any expression by the instructor that, even if unintentional, has the effect of belittling, humiliating, or ridiculing students. This includes behaviors such as destructive feedback and speaking to students in a condescending manner.
Faculty treats students unfairly based on characteristics such as gender, ethnic background, religion, or social class.
